title: 110_hr1224
content: The "Strengthening Physical Education Act of 2007" defines key terms such as State educational agency, local educational agency, and Secretary of Education. The findings by Congress highlight the significant economic impact of obesity-related diseases and the lack of physical activity among young people. Section 1111(b) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include physical education requirements starting in the 2007-2008 school year. States are not required to meet physical education assessment requirements until then. Starting from the 2009-2010 school year, physical education proficiency assessments must be conducted at least once for students in grades 3 through 5, grades 6 through 9, and grades 10 through. Physical education proficiency assessments must be conducted at least once for students in grades 10 through 12. The Secretary of Education, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, will evaluate State and local physical education model programs for effectiveness and identify safeguards and risks associated with physical education programs. A website will be created to publish information on these programs. Additionally, a grant program will be established. The Secretary may award grants to State education agencies for physical education standards, curriculum development, and model programs. States must submit applications with detailed curriculum and fund usage plans. The Secretary may award grants to State education agencies for developing physical education standards, curriculum, and programs. Applications must meet requirements and show promise of achieving the Act's purpose. Priority is given to high-need agencies for equitable distribution of funds. The Secretary may award grants to State education agencies for developing physical education standards, curriculum, and programs. Grants must ensure equitable distribution among regions and can cover a 5-year period with the option to apply for additional funding. Funds must be used for developing, revising, or improving physical education curriculum and purchasing materials and equipment. The Secretary awards grants to State education agencies for physical education programs, curriculum, and staff training. States must provide matching funds. The Secretary also offers technical assistance and evaluates program effectiveness for reporting to Congress. Authorization of appropriations for the Act includes $30,000,000 for 2009, $70,000,000 for 2010, and $100,000,000 annually from 2011 to 2013, with funds available until expended.
